front.p: 1841 August 31: Octavius Hadfield to his father Joseph

body.p: I take up my pen to write you a few lines, as I hear there is a vessel about to sail for South America by which an English mail will be sent. I wrote last about a month ago to Maria & that when I was last here. Since that I have received a letter from Octavia dated March 31st. & one from Charles of Oct. '40, I try to thank them for their kind letters. I have been disappointed this morn: on receiving two "Records" of May 5 & 8 not to find a letter from home, but I have reason to be thankful in having heard so lately that you were all well with the exception of dear George, concerning whom I feel very anxious. I hope you have been better supplied with letters from me lately, as I suppose my letters give you as much pleasure as yours do me. I have not however been for a long time favoured with one from you. I have little to relate since I last wrote. My work continues I trust, to prosper among these people far beyond my most sanguine expectations or those I suppose of any in England. I baptised 31 adults a few days ago at Waikanae. I mentioned in my last letter my interesting visit to the other side of the Straits. I sometimes think however, that I have too much to do, & that consequently I do nothing properly, I am wasting my time & depriving myself of comfort for want of leisure for reading etc. I have been called over here by the arrival of the Governor, who with his various followers, including Mr. Dawson & Mr. Clark (from te Waimate) arrived here a few days ago. I have had a good deal of conversation with the Governor about the natives etc., he is very civil & kind; I dined with him a day or two ago; & seems inclined to uphold religion in the land to the best of his power. He was at church on Sunday when I preached, tho' it was a miserable day. Mr. Dawson is going on to Wanganui about 100 miles from this, I shall accompany him, as Mr. Mason has been expecting me for some time. Here are three thousand persons, (English), & no clergyman, I have had some strong hints to induce me to remain here till somebody comes but I cannot. The respectable people of the place & the government are very civil to me. There are a Mr. & Mrs. St Hill with whom I am residing who are always remarkably kind. We are expecting a bishop out here, I hope he may arrive soon. I do not much like the Church Missionary Society, there was a late letter from Mr. Vores to the "ordained missionaries" which has done no good, & I think there is one cut at me, but whatever they may say of my entering into other men's labours & those the labours of laymen, I treat such an insinuation with the contempt it deserves, none having ever preached the Gospel within 300 miles of my sphere of labour; but why speak of such subjects, were it not to show the ignorance of people at home in all that concerns the mission. I never write to them, neither shall I on these subjects. It is far from pleasant to have our motives misrepresented, our labours cramped etc. by our friends & those who are sitting at home enjoying the peace & comforts of life; but enough of this, nay too much, excuse my infirmity, but some people seem to have no regard in writing for the feelings of men, & we are all too susceptible of anything which looks like a reproof. Political news I grieve to find by the papers is very bad. May the Lord have mercy on our highly favoured yet ungrateful nation. Excuse this; I will write more fully when I have more leisure. Give my warmest love to all &
I have written to ask Alexander to come here on his way home shd. he visit England.
